												Best RTS game ever.  I used to play this game a lot in my youth.  The best thing about it, is you have no limit on how many troops you can create!  You just need to have enough resources and dwellings, as long as you have enough, you can create as big of an army as you want.  For those of you complaining about this game not working on Windows 10Here is how to make it work (and stop crashing):1. Go to your steam library, right click on "Cossacks: Back to War" and select "Properties"2. In "Properties", go to the "Local Files" tab, and select "Browse Local Files"3. Open the "bin" folder, then scroll down & find "csbtw" right click it & select "troubleshoot compatibility"4. After a moment you should get to a screen where you can select "Try Recommended Settings"5. Once you have selected it, you can click on "Test the Program" to do a test run of the game, then exit the game6. Now select "Next"  and then "Yes, save these settings for this program" it will then try to detect other issues7. After this, it should say that it is fixed, click on "Close"There you have it!  The game should now run fine without crashing on you, and you can change the game speed without problems. My only issue now is getting it to display in widescreen, other than that, it runs perfectly.  I found the above steps in a youtube video, and it worked.  I hope this helps.

												Though my hours are few I plan on adding many more, all I can say is this game is right up my alley and as a fan of history (specficially Protestant Prussia) I whole heartily approve of this game with some caveats:The common cry among the negatives reveiw is that it is not optimized for modern computers and that is true, was not the case for me but a common warning nevertheless.It is quite different from modern RTS, wheras modern RTS have since had their shift focused more on the combat and less on the economy (or reducing it to 2-3 resources) this game I find is a balance, you need a good economy to make a good military which unlike most modern RTS is set in the 17th-18th century.Gameplay wise, while every nation has roughly identical units (to a greater or lesser degree, some nations have completely unique and distinct units) their sprites are distinct for each nation, culture and people (hell, you can set wars between Prussia and Bavaria in what was once vestige states of the "Holy" Roman Catholic Empire, 100 points to Martin Luther for smashing that to peices).I highly recacomend this game, doubly so if you computer has Windows XP virtual drive.
